segment.source: What is BitLocker recovery?
segment.target: What is BitLocker recovery?

segment.source: BitLocker recovery is the process by which you can restore access to a BitLocker-protected drive in the event that you cannot unlock the drive normally.
segment.target: BitLocker recovery is the process by which you can restore access to a BitLocker-protected drive in the event that you cannot unlock the drive normally.

segment.source: In a recovery scenario you have the following options to restore access to the drive:
segment.target: In a recovery scenario you have the following options to restore access to the drive:

segment.source: The user can supply the recovery password.
segment.target: The user can supply the recovery password.

segment.source: If your organization allows users to print or store recovery passwords, the user can type in the 48-digit recovery password that they printed or stored on a USB drive or with your Microsoft Account online.
segment.target: If your organization allows users to print or store recovery passwords, the user can type in the 48-digit recovery password that they printed or stored on a USB drive or with your Microsoft Account online.

segment.source: (Saving a recovery password with your Microsoft Account online is only allowed when BitLocker is used on a PC that is not a member of a domain).
segment.target: (Saving a recovery password with your Microsoft Account online is only allowed when BitLocker is used on a PC that is not a member of a domain).

segment.source: A data recovery agent can use their credentials to unlock the drive.
segment.target: A data recovery agent can use their credentials to unlock the drive.

segment.source: If the drive is an operating system drive, the drive must be mounted as a data drive on another computer for the data recovery agent to unlock it.
segment.target: If the drive is an operating system drive, the drive must be mounted as a data drive on another computer for the data recovery agent to unlock it.

segment.source: A domain administrator can obtain the recovery password from AD DS and use it to unlock the drive.
segment.target: A domain administrator can obtain the recovery password from AD DS and use it to unlock the drive.

segment.source: Storing recovery passwords in AD DS is recommended to provide a way for IT professionals to be able to obtain recovery passwords for drives in their organization if needed.
segment.target: Storing recovery passwords in AD DS is recommended to provide a way for IT professionals to be able to obtain recovery passwords for drives in their organization if needed.

segment.source: On PCs that use either BitLocker or Device Encryption when an attack is detected the device will immediately reboot and enter into BitLocker recovery mode.
segment.target: On PCs that use either BitLocker or Device Encryption when an attack is detected the device will immediately reboot and enter into BitLocker recovery mode.

segment.source: To take advantage of this functionality Administrators can set the Interactive logon: Machine account lockout threshold Group Policy setting located in Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options in the Local Group Policy Editor, or use the MaxFailedPasswordAttempts policy of Exchange ActiveSync (also configurable through Windows Intune), to limit the number of failed password attempts before the device goes into Device Lockout.
segment.target: To take advantage of this functionality Administrators can set the Interactive logon: Machine account lockout threshold Group Policy setting located in Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options in the Local Group Policy Editor, or use the MaxFailedPasswordAttempts policy of Exchange ActiveSync (also configurable through Windows Intune), to limit the number of failed password attempts before the device goes into Device Lockout.

segment.source: Changing the boot order to boot another drive in advance of the hard drive.
segment.target: Changing the boot order to boot another drive in advance of the hard drive.

segment.source: Having the CD or DVD drive before the hard drive in the BIOS boot order and then inserting or removing a CD or DVD.
segment.target: Having the CD or DVD drive before the hard drive in the BIOS boot order and then inserting or removing a CD or DVD.

segment.source: Failing to boot from a network drive before booting from the hard drive.
segment.target: Failing to boot from a network drive before booting from the hard drive.

segment.source: Docking or undocking a portable computer.
segment.target: Docking or undocking a portable computer.

segment.source: In some instances (depending on the computer manufacturer and the BIOS), the docking condition of the portable computer is part of the system measurement and must be consistent to validate the system status and unlock BitLocker.
segment.target: In some instances (depending on the computer manufacturer and the BIOS), the docking condition of the portable computer is part of the system measurement and must be consistent to validate the system status and unlock BitLocker.

segment.source: This means that if a portable computer is connected to its docking station when BitLocker is turned on, then it might also need to be connected to the docking station when it is unlocked.
segment.target: This means that if a portable computer is connected to its docking station when BitLocker is turned on, then it might also need to be connected to the docking station when it is unlocked.

segment.source: Conversely, if a portable computer is not connected to its docking station when BitLocker is turned on, then it might need to be disconnected from the docking station when it is unlocked.
segment.target: Conversely, if a portable computer is not connected to its docking station when BitLocker is turned on, then it might need to be disconnected from the docking station when it is unlocked.

segment.source: Changes to the NTFS partition table on the disk including creating, deleting, or resizing a primary partition.
segment.target: Changes to the NTFS partition table on the disk including creating, deleting, or resizing a primary partition.

segment.source: Entering the personal identification number (PIN) incorrectly too many times so that the anti-hammering logic of the TPM is activated.
segment.target: Entering the personal identification number (PIN) incorrectly too many times so that the anti-hammering logic of the TPM is activated.

segment.source: Anti-hammering logic is software or hardware methods that increase the difficulty and cost of a brute force attack on a PIN by not accepting PIN entries until after a certain amount of time has passed.
segment.target: Anti-hammering logic is software or hardware methods that increase the difficulty and cost of a brute force attack on a PIN by not accepting PIN entries until after a certain amount of time has passed.

segment.source: Turning off the support for reading the USB device in the pre-boot environment from the BIOS or UEFI firmware if you are using USB-based keys instead of a TPM.
segment.target: Turning off the support for reading the USB device in the pre-boot environment from the BIOS or UEFI firmware if you are using USB-based keys instead of a TPM.

segment.source: Turning off, disabling, deactivating, or clearing the TPM.
segment.target: Turning off, disabling, deactivating, or clearing the TPM.

segment.source: Upgrading critical early startup components, such as a BIOS or UEFI firmware upgrade, causing the related boot measurements to change.
segment.target: Upgrading critical early startup components, such as a BIOS or UEFI firmware upgrade, causing the related boot measurements to change.

segment.source: Forgetting the PIN when PIN authentication has been enabled.
segment.target: Forgetting the PIN when PIN authentication has been enabled.

segment.source: Updating option ROM firmware.
segment.target: Updating option ROM firmware.

segment.source: Upgrading TPM firmware.
segment.target: Upgrading TPM firmware.

segment.source: Adding or removing hardware; for example, inserting a new card in the computer, including some PCMIA wireless cards.
segment.target: Adding or removing hardware; for example, inserting a new card in the computer, including some PCMIA wireless cards.

segment.source: Removing, inserting, or completely depleting the charge on a smart battery on a portable computer.
segment.target: Removing, inserting, or completely depleting the charge on a smart battery on a portable computer.

segment.source: Changes to the master boot record on the disk.
segment.target: Changes to the master boot record on the disk.

segment.source: Changes to the boot manager on the disk.
segment.target: Changes to the boot manager on the disk.

segment.source: Hiding the TPM from the operating system.
segment.target: Hiding the TPM from the operating system.

segment.source: Some BIOS or UEFI settings can be used to prevent the enumeration of the TPM to the operating system.
segment.target: Some BIOS or UEFI settings can be used to prevent the enumeration of the TPM to the operating system.

segment.source: When implemented, this option can make the TPM hidden from the operating system.
segment.target: When implemented, this option can make the TPM hidden from the operating system.

segment.source: When the TPM is hidden, BIOS and UEFI secure startup are disabled, and the TPM does not respond to commands from any software.
segment.target: When the TPM is hidden, BIOS and UEFI secure startup are disabled, and the TPM does not respond to commands from any software.

segment.source: Using a different keyboard that does not correctly enter the PIN or whose keyboard map does not match the keyboard map assumed by the pre-boot environment.
segment.target: Using a different keyboard that does not correctly enter the PIN or whose keyboard map does not match the keyboard map assumed by the pre-boot environment.

segment.source: This can prevent the entry of enhanced PINs.
segment.target: This can prevent the entry of enhanced PINs.

segment.source: Modifying the Platform Configuration Registers (PCRs) used by the TPM validation profile.
segment.target: Modifying the Platform Configuration Registers (PCRs) used by the TPM validation profile.

segment.source: For example, including PCR1 would result in BitLocker measuring most changes to BIOS settings, causing BitLocker to enter recovery mode even when non-boot critical BIOS settings change.
segment.target: For example, including PCR1 would result in BitLocker measuring most changes to BIOS settings, causing BitLocker to enter recovery mode even when non-boot critical BIOS settings change.

segment.source: Note: Some computers have BIOS settings that skip measurements to certain PCRs, such as PCR2.
segment.target: Note: Some computers have BIOS settings that skip measurements to certain PCRs, such as PCR2.

segment.source: Changing this setting in the BIOS would cause BitLocker to enter recovery mode because the PCR measurement will be different.
segment.target: Changing this setting in the BIOS would cause BitLocker to enter recovery mode because the PCR measurement will be different.

segment.source: Moving the BitLocker-protected drive into a new computer.
segment.target: Moving the BitLocker-protected drive into a new computer.

segment.source: Upgrading the motherboard to a new one with a new TPM.
segment.target: Upgrading the motherboard to a new one with a new TPM.

segment.source: Losing the USB flash drive containing the startup key when startup key authentication has been enabled.
segment.target: Losing the USB flash drive containing the startup key when startup key authentication has been enabled.

segment.source: Failing the TPM self-test.
segment.target: Failing the TPM self-test.

segment.source: Having a BIOS, UEFI firmware, or an option ROM component that is not compliant with the relevant Trusted Computing Group standards for a client computer.
segment.target: Having a BIOS, UEFI firmware, or an option ROM component that is not compliant with the relevant Trusted Computing Group standards for a client computer.

segment.source: For example, a non-compliant implementation may record volatile data (such as time) in the TPM measurements, causing different measurements on each startup and causing BitLocker to start in recovery mode.
segment.target: For example, a non-compliant implementation may record volatile data (such as time) in the TPM measurements, causing different measurements on each startup and causing BitLocker to start in recovery mode.

segment.source: Changing the usage authorization for the storage root key of the TPM to a non-zero value.
segment.target: Changing the usage authorization for the storage root key of the TPM to a non-zero value.

segment.source: Note: The BitLocker TPM initialization process sets the usage authorization value to zero, so another user or process must explicitly have changed this value.
segment.target: Note: The BitLocker TPM initialization process sets the usage authorization value to zero, so another user or process must explicitly have changed this value.

segment.source: Disabling the code integrity check or enabling test signing on Windows Boot Manager (Bootmgr).
segment.target: Disabling the code integrity check or enabling test signing on Windows Boot Manager (Bootmgr).

segment.source: Pressing the F8 or F10 key during the boot process.
segment.target: Pressing the F8 or F10 key during the boot process.

segment.source: Adding or removing add-in cards (such as video or network cards), or upgrading firmware on add-in cards.
segment.target: Adding or removing add-in cards (such as video or network cards), or upgrading firmware on add-in cards.

segment.source: Using a BIOS hot key during the boot process to change the boot order to something other than the hard drive.
segment.target: Using a BIOS hot key during the boot process to change the boot order to something other than the hard drive.

segment.source: After the recovery password has been used to recover access to the PC, BitLocker will reseal the encryption key to the current values of the measured components.
segment.target: After the recovery password has been used to recover access to the PC, BitLocker will reseal the encryption key to the current values of the measured components.

segment.source: For planned scenarios, such as a known hardware or firmware upgrades, you can avoid initiating recovery by temporarily suspending BitLocker protection.
segment.target: For planned scenarios, such as a known hardware or firmware upgrades, you can avoid initiating recovery by temporarily suspending BitLocker protection.

segment.source: Because suspending BitLocker leaves the drive fully encrypted, the administrator can quickly resume BitLocker protection after the planned task has been completed.
segment.target: Because suspending BitLocker leaves the drive fully encrypted, the administrator can quickly resume BitLocker protection after the planned task has been completed.

segment.source: Using suspend and resume also reseals the encryption key without requiring the entry of the recovery key.
segment.target: Using suspend and resume also reseals the encryption key without requiring the entry of the recovery key.

segment.source: Note: If suspended BitLocker will automatically resume protection when the PC is rebooted, unless a reboot count is specified using the manage-bde command line tool.
segment.target: Note: If suspended BitLocker will automatically resume protection when the PC is rebooted, unless a reboot count is specified using the manage-bde command line tool.

segment.source: Post-recovery analysis
segment.target: Post-recovery analysis

segment.source: When a volume is unlocked using a recovery password, an event is written to the event log and the platform validation measurements are reset in the TPM to match the current configuration.
segment.target: When a volume is unlocked using a recovery password, an event is written to the event log and the platform validation measurements are reset in the TPM to match the current configuration.

segment.source: Unlocking the volume means that the encryption key has been released and is ready for on-the-fly encryption when data is written to the volume, and on-the-fly decryption when data is read from the volume.
segment.target: Unlocking the volume means that the encryption key has been released and is ready for on-the-fly encryption when data is written to the volume, and on-the-fly decryption when data is read from the volume.

segment.source: After the volume is unlocked, BitLocker behaves the same way, regardless of how the access was granted.
segment.target: After the volume is unlocked, BitLocker behaves the same way, regardless of how the access was granted.

segment.source: If you notice that a computer is having repeated recovery password unlocks, you might want to have an administrator can perform post-recovery analysis to determine the root cause of the recovery and refresh BitLocker platform validation so that the user no longer needs to enter a recovery password each time that the computer starts up.

segment.source: Review and answer the following questions for your organization:
segment.target: Review and answer the following questions for your organization:

segment.source: What BitLocker protection mode is in effect (TPM, TPM + PIN, TPM + startup key, startup key only)?

segment.target: Did the user merely forget the PIN or lose the startup key?

segment.source: If a token was lost, where might the token be?
segment.target: If a token was lost, where might the token be?

segment.source: If TPM mode was in effect, was recovery caused by a boot file change?
segment.target: If TPM mode was in effect, was recovery caused by a boot file change?

segment.source: If recovery was caused by a boot file change, is this due to an intended user action (for example, BIOS upgrade), or to malicious software?
segment.target: If recovery was caused by a boot file change, is this due to an intended user action (for example, BIOS upgrade), or to malicious software?

segment.source: When was the user last able to start the computer successfully, and what might have happened to the computer since then?
segment.target: When was the user last able to start the computer successfully, and what might have happened to the computer since then?

segment.source: Might the user have encountered malicious software or left the computer unattended since the last successful startup?
segment.target: Might the user have encountered malicious software or left the computer unattended since the last successful startup?

segment.source: To help you answer these questions, use the BitLocker command-line tool to view the current configuration and protection mode (for example, manage-bde -status).

segment.source: Windows RE and BitLocker
segment.target: Windows RE and BitLocker

segment.source: Windows Recovery Environment (RE) can be used to recover access to a drive protected by BitLocker or by Device Encryption.
segment.target: Windows Recovery Environment (RE) can be used to recover access to a drive protected by BitLocker or by Device Encryption.

segment.source: If a PC is unable to boot after two failures, Startup Repair will automatically start.
segment.target: If a PC is unable to boot after two failures, Startup Repair will automatically start.

segment.source: When Startup Repair is launched automatically due to boot failures, it will only execute operating system and driver file repairs, provided that the boot logs or any available crash dump point to a specific corrupted file.
segment.target: When Startup Repair is launched automatically due to boot failures, it will only execute operating system and driver file repairs, provided that the boot logs or any available crash dump point to a specific corrupted file.

segment.source: In Windows 8.1 and later, devices that include firmware to support specific TPM measurements for PCR7 the TPM can validate that Windows RE is a trusted operating environment and will unlock any BitLocker-protected drives if Windows RE has not been modified.
segment.target: In Windows 8.1 and later, devices that include firmware to support specific TPM measurements for PCR7 the TPM can validate that Windows RE is a trusted operating environment and will unlock any BitLocker-protected drives if Windows RE has not been modified.

segment.source: If the Windows RE environment has been modified, for example the TPM has been disabled, the drives will stay locked until the BitLocker recovery key is provided.
segment.target: If the Windows RE environment has been modified, for example the TPM has been disabled, the drives will stay locked until the BitLocker recovery key is provided.

segment.source: If Startup Repair is not able to be run automatically from the PC and instead Windows RE is manually started from a repair disk, the BitLocker recovery key must be provided to unlock the BitLocker–protected drives.
segment.target: If Startup Repair is not able to be run automatically from the PC and instead Windows RE is manually started from a repair disk, the BitLocker recovery key must be provided to unlock the BitLocker–protected drives.
